@rabbah Now that I understand a bit more, I think the `fqn` on rules and sequences are not really necessary. In fact, I think some of the sequence tests use both fqn's and relative names, which test both usage patterns. As you pointed out, if we do add the `fqn`s everywhere, we're missing on some type of tests. I think it's better to leave them out and just submit the "real" fix (the env override).

PG3 43

Should we add a step in the nginx role to check that is up after docker run for nginx?

All the other container roles have a step in their deploy.yml to wait/check that the container is and functional, for example Controller "wait until the Controller in this host is up and running"
- [consul](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/roles/consul/tasks/deploy.yml#L52)
- [controller](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/roles/controller/tasks/deploy.yml#L40)
- [couchdb](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/roles/couchdb/tasks/deploy.yml#L32)
- [invoker](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/roles/invoker/tasks/deploy.yml#L51)
- [kafka](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/roles/kafka/tasks/deploy.yml#L41)

In addition we could add a wait/check that wsk api is up (i.e. http get $edge/api/v1) before trying to use the wsk cli to install any package/action.

Thanks @domdom82 for the fix üëç

@rabbah - Here's the addition to the Wsk.scala common test tooling for your feedback.  In the meantime, I'll be creating additional tests based on this structure.

I vaguely recall now.   It originated in blue-green testing of the CLI.

When swapping from blue to green, we would first run regression tests on the green cluster, and then swap if tests all passed.   For the initial set of tests in green, the "cli api host" would be the green edge.    Of course the CLI used by customers would always point to router host.

I think at some point we changed the tests to use a different flag with cli set property api.host, but the ansible variable is probably legacy from the days when the CLI_API_HOST was a build-time property of the CLI.    This is old stuff -- python CLI and pre-ansible.
is there a companion to this?

Had to do it again since the build was broken. Everything is squashed to my taste now. We just have to wait for the green lights.

The cli.api.host is the dns name per environment (e.g. "openwhisk.ng.bluemix.net")
The router.host is the actual host, e.g. "123.123.123.123"

Which makes sense in scenarios where they are not the same, e.g. loadbalancers, proxies etc.

Also `cli_api_host` is a property that is independent from the inventory, while `router.host` is always generated from the inventory of hosts for that particular environment.

@domdom82 thanks for the clarification. In open, the router is not used/deployed and there is only the edge. The cli.api.host is an ip address, not a name. Should we make it clean in open as well then and define api.host to a name or leave it be? The complication with a name is for mac e.g., where the localhost isn't good enough and one needs a `dockerhost` aliased.

Trying the steps above gives me a larger action. I suspect versions/dependencies may have changed:

    $ du -h action.zip
     42M    action.zip
    $ base64 action.zip | wc
       1       1 59079765

So the base64-encoded version is over 50M, and it hits the nginx limit (currently set to 50M). The request never even makes it to the controller.

Will try an action around 22M.

These steps seem to reproduce the issue without depending on `npm` versions:

    $ base64 /dev/urandom | head -c 28000000 > 28M.txt
    $ zip action.zip 28M.txt 
    adding: 29M.txt (deflated 24%)
    $ du -h action.zip 
     20M    action.zip
    $ wsk action create bigzip action.zip --kind nodejs:6
    error: Unable to create action: request entity too large (code 93)
The issue is that the controller measures the size of strings as the memory they use on the heap, while the natural expectation is to measure their bytesize in UTF8.
Rebased the primary commit and superseding in #1600.

Proposed fix in #1611: non-truthy errors are turned into `{}` (this includes `reject()`, which essentially maps to `return { error: undefined }`).

This is consistent with the current behavior of `return;` turning into `return {};`.

In one of the earlier comments, @sjfink suggested returning "null" to indicate action success but abort a sequence. This has the advantage that we don't have to use an "error" convention but violates the json object in/out abstraction.

Here's a proposal to admit "null" without necessarily changing the action's `Dictionary -> Dictionary` signature.

Suppose the signature of the action was `Option[Dictionary] => Option[Dictionary]`. Then one has to check the input to determine if it's defined or empty (that is, check if there is a value provided or none).

We can reconcile this with our current action signature by allowing actions to return a `Dictionary` or `null`, where the former is conceptually boxed to `Some[Dictionary]` and the latter is boxed to `None`. Then, we guarantee that when you invoke an action it's always `Some[Dictionary]` and never `None`. That is, if the argument is `None` your action is not invoked. In this way, the action is only allowed to map over the defined value and not the empty value. Another way to understand this is that an action receiving `Null` returns `Null` by definition.

From a composition point of view it's sound as in one can compose g(f(option)) as long as they only map on the option (in the Scala sense for example). From the sequence implementation point of view, the action returning `Null` aborts the rest of the sequence but the activation is recorded as having a successful status (and _not_ an error). (Somewhat formally our actions are `Try[Dictionary] => Try[Dictionary]` and this model changes the action signature to `Try[Some[Dictionary]] => Try[Option[Dictionary]]`.)

So the proposal (elaborating Steve's above) which is superior then using a convention on a reserved field:
1. allow `null` as a valid return from actions (note that `null` is a valid JSON value, not a JSON object)
2. modify the sequence scheduler so that it aborts execution (with status recorded as `success`) at the first action returning `null`
3. record the result as null in the activation record
4. actions must explicitly `return null` to indicate they are returning no value (that is a naked `return` otherwise continues to map to `return {}` for node actions).

In other words, I move to accept @sjfink's "Proposal: if an action returns "null", it is considered "success", but terminates a sequence." Thumbs up in favor, comments to elaborate or refine.

@domdom82 I propose we go for now with option 3, it will not break `vagrant up`

Add a script that user can run to patch the kernel. And then he will be able to run all the tests.
`vagrant up` doesn't run the tests automatically, only does a build and deploy, no tests.

user can run a single test, a set of tests if they want. 
We can update the doc README to tell them to run the kernel patch script reboot, it will be one time.

Later we there is an image we can use with no problems and new kernel we remove the instructions and the patch script.
